Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: The shrill site alarm jolts me from my work, and I drop my tools, heart pounding. Protocol is clear: when the alarm sounds, everyone must evacuate, no exceptions. My foreman’s voice echoes in my head—“No stragglers, no excuses.” I start toward the muster point with the others, boots crunching gravel, but my phone buzzes in my pocket. It’s a message from the synagogue: they need one more for the minyan, the quorum for the funeral prayer. Without me, the prayer can’t happen, and the mourners will be left waiting, their grief suspended. I glance at the huddle of workers ahead, then back at the message. My community expects me to be there, to honor the dead, but my job demands I follow safety rules, stay with my crew. My chest tightens as I weigh the urgency of both calls—one to safety, one to sacred duty. I stand frozen, torn between the blaring alarm and the silent plea of my faith, knowing I can’t be in two places at once.
